description:
First, family, friends, and fellow racing drivers have paid tribute to Jules Bianchi at his funeral in his hometown Nice in France. There were solemn applause as the family took the casket inside the cathedral, where the funeral took place. Bianchi died on Friday night, nine months after suffering head injury sustained in a crash at the Japanese Grand Prix. He was the first driver to die of an injury sustained in an F1 race since Ayrton Senna in 1994. Among those at the funeral was the French Formula One journalist Daniel Rotelli who knew Jules well.

"It was a fitting funeral because it was a beautiful ceremony, and because all sorts of drivers were here: young drivers, older drivers, current drivers. I didn't suspect we would see as many drivers three days before the Grand Prix. Everybody was crying, everybody was very moved, and I have to say it was a sad sad sad day, and it was also a beautiful ceremony, because the image of Jules in that ceremony was simple, it was modest, it was very strong, and it was just like him. He was 25 and he didn't have the best car by far length, but he never complained and he was always positive about what he was experiencing."
